messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] infinity the small way
messages.msgSnippet: Our 6 y.o. adores google - the concept, not the search engine (she s keen on the search engine come to think of it, but that s a different issue).  She can
messages.messageBody:
Our 6 y.o. adores google - the concept, not the search engine
(she's keen on the search engine come to think of it, but that's
a different issue). She can explain how operations for which she
has no name have to operate using google, but the mechanics of
cubing a "real" number stop her from explaining exponents nearly
as well as she can when it is a kewl place holder like google.
...and, no, I have no idea where she learned that google even
existed as a concept....
----- Original Message -----
From: "Pam Sorooshian" <pamsoroosh@...>
To: <unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, November 15, 2002 8:35 PM
Subject: [Unschooling-dotcom] infinity the small way


| I LOVED that Brenda!
|
| So -- now you've got some "infinity" conversation going -- what
you want is
| for him NOT to get the idea that infinity is some kind of
really really big
| number.
|
| You can ask him what happens when you keep dividing something
in half, over
| and over, now. Then you can talk about what happens if you
divide nothing
| in half <G>.
|
| These are MUCH more fun things to do with a 6 yo than to worry
about
| carrying and borrowing <G>. He'll get there -- don't worry -
keep having
| fun with ideas.
|
| --pam
|

messages.subject: infinity the small way
messages.msgSnippet: I LOVED that Brenda! So -- now you ve got some infinity conversation going -- what you want is for him NOT to get the idea that infinity is some kind of
messages.messageBody:
I LOVED that Brenda!

So -- now you've got some "infinity" conversation going -- what you want is
for him NOT to get the idea that infinity is some kind of really really big
number.

You can ask him what happens when you keep dividing something in half, over
and over, now. Then you can talk about what happens if you divide nothing
in half <G>.

These are MUCH more fun things to do with a 6 yo than to worry about
carrying and borrowing <G>. He'll get there -- don't worry - keep having
fun with ideas.

--pam

Pam Sorooshian
National Home Education Network
www.NHEN.org
Changing the Way the World Sees Homeschooling
